verses.text: After this, the king of the Ammonites died, and his son Hanun became king in his place.
verses.comment: Verse matches the Hebrew structure with no meaningful changes.

verses.text: David said, 'I will show kindness to Hanun son of Nahash, as his father showed kindness to me.' So David sent servants to comfort him about his father. David's servants came to the land of the Ammonites.
verses.comment: Structure simplified for clarity, but preserves all original meanings.

verses.text: But the princes of the Ammonites said to Hanun, 'Do you think David is honoring your father by sending comforters to you? Hasn't David sent his servants to you to search the city, to spy it out, and to overthrow it?'
verses.comment: Language made colloquial but remains faithful to the original accusation and meaning.

verses.text: So Hanun took David’s servants, shaved off half of each man's beard, cut off their garments in the middle at the hips, and sent them away.
verses.comment: Retains the original humiliation described in the Hebrew text.

verses.text: When they told David, he sent messengers to meet them, for the men were deeply ashamed. The king said, 'Stay at Jericho until your beards have grown, and then return.'
verses.comment: Remains word-for-word except for 'deeply ashamed' for clarity.

verses.text: When the Ammonites saw that they had become hateful to David, they sent and hired the Arameans of Beth-rehob and the Arameans of Zobah, twenty thousand foot soldiers, and the king of Maacah with one thousand men, and the men of Tob, twelve thousand men.
verses.comment: Foot soldiers specified for clarity; names and numbers preserved.

verses.text: When David heard of it, he sent Joab and all the army with mighty warriors.
verses.comment: The phrase 'the army of the mighty' rendered as 'all the army with mighty warriors' for clarity.

verses.text: And the Ammonites came out and lined up for battle at the entrance of the gate. The Arameans of Zobah and Rehob and the men of Tob and Maacah stood apart in the open country.
verses.comment: Uses 'lined up for battle' to clarify the military formation.

verses.text: When Joab saw that the battle was set against him both in front and behind, he chose part of all the best men of Israel, and arranged them against the Arameans.
verses.comment: Joab's tactical response is kept literal and concise.

verses.text: The rest of the men he put under the command of Abishai, his brother, and arranged them against the Ammonites.
verses.comment: Literal rendering of division of forces.

verses.text: Joab said, 'If the Arameans are too strong for me, you will help me; but if the Ammonites are too strong for you, I will come to help you.'
verses.comment: Faithful to original structure and meaning.

verses.text: 'Be courageous, and let us be strong for our people and for the cities of our God. And may the LORD do what is good in his sight.'
verses.comment: The encouragement to courage and reliance on the LORD kept word-for-word.

verses.text: So Joab and the troops with him advanced to fight against the Arameans, and they fled before him.
verses.comment: Simple verse, closely matching original Hebrew.

verses.text: When the Ammonites saw that the Arameans had fled, they also fled from Abishai and entered the city. Then Joab returned from fighting the Ammonites and came to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Sequence of retreat kept; added 'returned from fighting' for clarity.

verses.text: When the Arameans saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they gathered themselves together.
verses.comment: Matches the Hebrew structure; 'defeated' clarifies the meaning.

verses.text: Hadadezer sent and brought out the Arameans who were beyond the Euphrates River; they came to Helam, with Shobach, the commander of Hadadezer’s army, leading them.
verses.comment: Euphrates River named for clarity; 'beyond' reflects eastern geography.

verses.text: When this was reported to David, he gathered all Israel, crossed the Jordan, and came to Helam. The Arameans formed their lines against David and fought him.
verses.comment: Direct translation; 'formed their lines' for military clarity.

verses.text: The Arameans fled before Israel, and David killed seven hundred charioteers and forty thousand horsemen of the Arameans, and he struck down Shobach, commander of their army, who died there.
verses.comment: Numbers match the Hebrew Masoretic text. 1 Chron. 19:18 records seven thousand charioteers, a difference. Original meaning preserved.

verses.text: When all the kings who were servants of Hadadezer saw that they were defeated by Israel, they made peace with Israel and became their subjects. So the Arameans feared to help the Ammonites any more.
verses.comment: Summary kept clear and accurate. 'Subjects' rendered for 'served them.'
